BE11:30am

Self-regulation theme continues to grow… The joint statement today from Flutter, GVC, Sky Bet, William Hill and bet365 (the biggest UK operators) builds on investor’s growing awareness of gambling self-regulation. In the statement, the companies highlight the need for a ‘step change in how we tackle gambling-related harm.’

Excel Developer @red: did you see iron ore shoot up yesterday? https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/iron-ore-price
red @Excel Developerlagarde. 50bps cuts touted. doesnt help is a politician. so runners will need to do all the work. lane suggested by ms or maybe jpm forget now.
Tom Dalgleish @Excel, over here are stories of WA iron ore exporters missing export targets
BE11:31am

Cohesive self-regulation marks a crucial turning point for the sector: barriers to entry rise and the risk of future punitive regulation reduces (which is the market’s biggest fear). Over time, we think self-regulation could lead to a re-rating. Two weeks ago, the leading operators stated an intention to contribute 10x more than they are required to towards problem gambling treatment and safer gambling measures. Today’s statement is effectively an extension of that commitment with further details on the measures (treatment, advertising, transparency and data sharing).

red yup highest since 2014.
11:31 am
BE11:31am

There are 3 areas of interest. 1] The statement suggesting there will be further data sharing between operators to protect problem gamblers from experiencing further harm ... . 2] Advertising will change, with greater emphasis on safer gambling measures, and advertising technology will be utilised to divert messages from problem gamblers where possible. 3) Finally we note that the companies will report publically on progress: this is also new and over time this transparency could help improve the relationship between operators, regulators, politicians and other stakeholders.

Excel Developer @Tom: WA = western Australia
BE11:32am

Flutter now 18% live. Gonna look a bit snide if a statement is required .....

Tom Dalgleish Yes
BE11:32am

We think further self-regulation measures could be announced on topics such as 1) highlighting online markers for harm, 2) promoting consistent interactions and interventions with players exhibiting markers for harm, 3) introducing consistent online tools to reduce gambling harm, 4) potential sponsorship bans, 5) sharing best practice. We also think executive pay could be linked to responsible gambling measures in the future. We continue to think self-regulation needs to happen to avoid the structural bear case playing out: higher taxes, punitive regulation, downgrades, decreasing investor confidence in cash flow forecasts and a de-rating.

Tom Dalgleish weather related

We view the recent sell-off in the online gaming sector as an opportunity to invest in cheap internet-driven companies that target structural growth markets and also trade at a deep valuation discount. These companies offer high margins, and in aggregate, they offer a 10% EBITDA CAGR over the next two years. We see the scope to create value from another wave of consolidation, with rising regulatory and marketing costs encouraging a drive for scale, given material cost synergies.We are initiating coverage of the online gaming sector. We have: GVC as a Buy, with a 910p target price; JPJ Group as a Buy, with a 1000p target price; William Hill as a Buy, with a 197p target price; 888 as a Hold, with a 175p target price; Flutter as a Hold, with a 5750p target price; Playtech as a Hold with a 460p target price; and Stars Group as a Hold with a C$24 target price.

Chipmaker Broadcom is nearing a deal to buy US cyber security group Symantec in a transaction that could be worth more than $15bn, according to people briefed about the negotiations.

A deal could be announced as early as Wednesday, although those briefed on the talks warned that no final agreement had been signed and the announcement could be delayed until after the US public holiday on July 4.

BE11:42am

Symantec popped 20% or so after hours.

Excel Developer that FT link above is Neil Hume, formerly of this parish.
BE11:43am

Leading the sector up, after the sector was hit a fair bit recently.

11:43 am

Largely on slowing renewals etc. And you'll remember that Symantec had a financial whistleblower last year, though it was never entirely clear what they were blowing the whistle about.

Avast PLC (AVST:LSE): Last: 317.40, up 10.4 (+3.39%), High: 322.00, Low: 312.00, Volume: 1.41m
Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 430.70, up 39.5 (+10.10%), High: 445.60, Low: 404.50, Volume: 2.02m

11:44 am
BE11:44am

........ which is also subject to a JPM upgrade. We'll come to that in a bit.

BE11:45am

So .... is this Broadcom starting a consolidation wave for nagware providers or is it just picking off a distressed play for a bit of sideways expansion?

BE11:46am

Neil Campling says it's the latter.

Excel Developer and his twitter feed https://twitter.com/humenm (love the muppets reference)
11:46 am
BE11:47am

Symantec is primarily an antivirus business and the consumer business is still 50% of revenues (FY19 to End March 2019), which grew by just 5% YoY. And the enterprise business declined 9% YoY and the latest quarter saw a massive miss on Enterprise billings -24% YoY. The cloud based endpoint solution hasn’t even been rolled out yet, the company is losing market share in endpoint and web security according to CSO surveys, and the company has been slow to pivot to cloud security and analytics. The company is vulnerable to a deal given the incumbent CEO was ousted in May.

A. M. @BE: is broadcom aiming at some sort of vertical integration (of what?)
red yes think agree with campling. not sure folks will be falling over to pay premium for likes of sophos which u ae never sure is growing quickly.
BE11:48am

So .... Broadcom's flatlining. They're buying growth.

BE11:48am

At Broadcom’s last earnings call, 13th June, CEO Hock Tan indicated that there were deals of interest in the market: “we continue to be very interested in opportunities that may present themselves, and we continue to be very active in assessing those opportunities”. If Broadcom make a move for Symantec then, it is one that is financially motivated we think. One of the few things that has grown in recent times for Symantec is cash flow. Over the last 12 months Symantec’s FCF has grown by 59% YoY to reach $1.29B giving the company a healthy 9% FCF Yield. And that is probably what motivates Broadcom which has been a serial acquirer, first of product franchise lines in semiconductors (they have 18 lines of business in this arena now), then into software with CA’s enterprise customers complementing the silicon customer base. When Broadcom does a deal they look at the acquisition target as having to justify Broadcom’s “acquisition economics”; taking an undervalued franchise, integrating into the Broadcom portfolio, divesting non-core products, run the business with a focus on returns. The CA example was taking a $20B revenue business that was a capex light business, running free cash flow conversion on a levered basis north of 40%.

red @A. M.yes its a strange one. symantec not exactly rev busting
A. M. Perhaps it's a swiss-cheese model, where software offsets hardware security flaws and vice-versa.
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Or Piper, if you prefer.

BE11:50am

[W]e feel Symantec would make a perfect fit for the Broadcom portfolio. The situation reminds us of the CA acquisition in mid-2018, which ultimately turned out be extremely successful under the Broadcom umbrella. From our point of view, there are striking similarities between Symantec and CA.

BE11:50am

Justified by a lot of sackings.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Symantec spends a lot of money on SGA at roughly 37%
to 39% in any given quarter. Specifically, sales and marketing alone represented 29.2% in the March quarter, with general and administrative expenses representing 7.1%. Additionally, R&D was 16.7% of revenue in the latest quarter. It is our understanding that at least two-thirds of R&D is spent on the enterprise side. If a deal were finalized, it is possible that Broadcom could shut down or sell off pieces of the enterprise division that it deems as non-performing (similar to the Veracode divestiture for CA).

BE11:51am

Overall, we would expect Broadcom to execute a very similar strategy with Symantec as it did with CA if a deal were to happen. We see Broadcom driving deeper relationships with selected customers in order to leverage the SG&A costs while abandoning the pursuit of new customers. In addition, we can see an extension of the “all-you-can-eat” strategy with Symantec as well, allowing Broadcom to further penetrate select customers.

PeterC Would have thought AVST would be better read across, on 10% FCF yield near enough. Cheap to a buyer (no position) SOPH a dog relative to it's US peers
BE11:52am

Barclays makes the same arguments.

Tim Benzedrine Every ecosystem gets its own predators, Broadcom remains, like Computer Associates back in the day, a sort of elephant graveyard of financial predation: a place where slowing and failing technology companies are bundled up neatly for investors who don't know better, and who think leverage would make an excellent Netflix series.
11:52 am
BE11:52am

Not surprising that there is interest given: (1) management change; (2) active investors. Last quarter was challenging for Symantec – they came in below on Enterprise billings in its seasonally strong quarter, and the well-known CEO Greg Clark stepped down. In addition, CFO Nick Noviello announced he was leaving in prior quarters, with new CFO Vincent Pilette stepping in recently. In addition, remember there are several active investors involved with Symantec, including Silver Lake, Bain Capital and Starboard Value, so it is not surprising that there may be some desire for change to drive shareholder value.

Reminds us of CA at first blush. This will not be Broadcom’s first foray into software, after acquiring Computer Associates (CA) in 2018. While Symantec and CA serve different markets, we see some similarities in profile like: (1) mature growth at scale; (2) good software margins with the opportunity for more optimization; (3) strong cash flow; and (4) inexpensive valuation at the time of acquisition.

BE11:53am

....... so, if this is a special sit that's as much to do with cheap debt as strategic benefit, why are Avast and Sophos up so sharp?

red exactly
Tim Benzedrine The irony, of course, is that Broadcom bought CA, an early practitioner of this strategy, so it's delightful watching tech infect and then consume itself, in a sort of flesh-wasting disease accelerated by leverage.
BE11:54am

I don't know! And neither does Jefferies.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We believe Broadcom's strategy has been to optimize the CA business for profitability, and this would likely also be the case with SYMC. We believe SYMC has c.40% of the consumer endpoint market. We see mixed readacross for Avast: an increased focus on cash generation would suggest less of an effort to acquire new customers, potentially reducing competition. However, an increased focus on customer retention could challenge volume growth for Avast, as SYMC has been a market share donor in consumer AV.

red though i expect both were marked up and dumb money comes in

Grouchmonkey @Excel if that's the driver would expect more reaction from Rio and BHP share prices
BE11:56am

Bad YE2019 makes for a good YE2020 in comparison. That's the gist.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

We believe Sophos’ equity narrative has shifted meaningfully, driven by a
number of factors: 1) we have progressed past FY19, which was
challenging year-over-year due to tough comps, hardware refresh cycles
extending and a mix shift taking place; 2) following a tough FY19 and
multiple guidance misses, we think management has been more
conservative in providing expectations for FY20; 3) Q1 is an important
catalyst, and we think the setup is favourable (we model ~7% cc billings
growth, a strong acceleration from the mid-single digit declines in Q4’19);
and 4) billings should sequentially accelerate QoQ through FY20 from the
Q4’19 trough, helped by new products EDR and v.17.5 XG Firewall.
Momentum is the key driver of the shares, in our view, and we believe
we are at an inflection point. Consensus earnings momentum should
pick up from here, which would in turn drive the current trading
multiples off the low end of their historical ranges. As a result, we
upgrade Sophos from N to OW, and lift our PT from 385p to 480p

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Results are largely irrelevant. Growing revenue, wider loss. Usual stuff.

BE12:01pm

Peel Hunt can summarise.

BE12:01pm

Full year revenues increased by 55% to £137m, however, operating losses widened to £52m (FY18: £28m) driven by £53m of losses from the US and Australian businesses. The UK business performed well against a difficult market backdrop with revenues ahead by 21% to £90m. This was driven by an 8.6% rise in instructions (to c70,000) and a 6.4% rise in average revenue per instruction to £1,243. Ancillary revenues rose marginally to 44% of revenues (FY18: 43%) and lettings revenues increased by over 10%. UK operating profits rose to £5.3m with an operating margin of 5.9% (FY18: 3.0%). The Canadian business, in its first full year of ownership, reported revenues of £24m and an operating loss of £3.2m. The balance sheet had net cash of £63m at the year end and management expects to end the current year with cash of between £40-50m.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

One day, maybe, we'll find out how many houses they sell rather than just sell STC.

BE12:02pm

Not today though. Peel Hunt says "work in progress, dunno".

BE12:02pm

With the decisions completed on the geographic footprint of the Group, the focus will now shift to the growth strategy. New CEO Vic Darvey will be working on a number of measures to drive further market share gains in the UK and Canada. Management has reiterated its medium term objective to gain 10% of the UK market (currently c4%). In Canada the aim is to maintain 20% market share in Quebec and increase brand awareness and market penetration in the remainder of Canada having rebranded to Purplebricks in early 2019. Investment in the Group’s brand and technology will continue, though there will be greater discipline around cash management and generation. For now, our forecasts and recommendation remain under review.

BE12:07pm

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is proposing rules to address harm to retail consumers from the sale of derivatives and exchange traded notes (ETNs) referencing certain types of cryptoassets.

The FCA considers these products are ill-suited to retail consumers who cannot reliably assess the value and risks of derivatives or ETNs that reference certain cryptoassets (crypto-derivatives). This is due to:

inherent nature of the underlying assets, which have no reliable basis for valuation
the prevalence of market abuse and financial crime in the secondary market for cryptoassets (eg cyber theft)
extreme volatility in cryptoasset prices movements, and
inadequate understanding by retail consumers of cryptoassets and the lack of a clear investment need for investment products referencing them
These features mean retail consumers might suffer harm from sudden and unexpected losses if they invest in these products.

BE12:17pm

Reduce our DCF derived TP to 175p from 310p. This is driven by lower loan origination volume assumptions. The recent de-rating leaves the current valuation of 1.9x 2020e revenue even after our 21% cut. Main downside risk is lower than expected loan originations (a function of lack of borrower demand or lack of lender supply). The next potential catalyst will be management’s 2020 guidance, which we would expect around the Q3 19 trading update. We now expect FCH to break-even on a reported EBITDA basis in 2024 versus 2021 previously.
